data.text: @teachbarefoot @benjamindickman I agree "generalized associativity" doesn't need to be introduced, but associativity is introduced in elementary school. We should be using the word almost every day in high school. (same thing with identity, inverse, and commutivity.) Just like we used distribution regularly!
@Ethan_MidPen @MsRobertsRoom @teachbarefoot I can never remember what collate means when submitting copies.

@teachbarefoot @gwaddellnvhs + I rarely broach "generalized associativity," which I saw only as a math major in a first course on abstract algebra, and for which the proof proceeded by [strong?] induction. Rigor mortis for my present purposes...

@teachbarefoot I call "commutativity" ... "reordering" & "associativity" ... "regrouping"

I'll still use the formal names for completeness. But, I think those terms - which I first saw preparing to teach math content courses for elementary school preservice teachers - are more descriptive!
@sjsbates @teachbarefoot I have to look that one up. I know there was once but it’s not ingrained like Conjuction Junction or Lolly Lolly Lolly
@teachbarefoot What did you search that you found it? Curious minds...
@mrburkemath @teachbarefoot I think articles are briefly mentioned in the adjective song.

@teachbarefoot But how could you look it up if you forgot what it was? Christ, it's just like when your elementary school teacher would tell you to look up a word in the dictionary if you didn't know how to spell it...
@MsRobertsRoom @teachbarefoot I regularly mix up the words reflexive and reflective for the geometry property, and have to look it up every year before teaching it.
@teachbarefoot What do you mean you use binary operators everyday without thinking of each and every property they have? https://t.co/0uSbYPkSGZ
